Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Liquid Chromatography/Mass Spectrometer for Accurate Mass Determination and Complex Mixture Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Patrick Willoughby from Ripon College and colleagues Colleen Byron and Robert Wallace will acquire a liquid chromatograph, time-of-flight mass spectrometer capable of providing accurate mass (LCMS-TOF-accurate mass). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph provides additional structural identification power by separating mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. As a primarily undergraduate institution, Ripon's faculty embraces undergraduate research experiences as one of the most important outcomes of their research activities. The proposed instrument will directly impact the research experiences of a large number of students within the three-year project period, and many more in years to come. Undergraduate researchers will participate in activities with high schools. This instrument will also be shared with researchers from the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh as well as those from Lawrence University.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) developing new organic synthesis methodology involving acyl radicals and photoredox catalysis; (b) optimizing conditions for the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction of o-benzyne with a carbonyl ylide; (c) study the effects of byproducts of reactive oxygen species on electron-transferring proteins; and (d) studying the effect of lipid profiles on rotifer survival and the unpalatability of rotifer colonies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2014, Ripon College acquired a new liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (i.e., LC/MS) instrument using funds awarded by the NSF via the Major Research Instrumentation (i.e., MRI) program. The LC/MS system is an Agilent 6230BA accurate mass time-of-flight (i.e., TOF) mass spectrometer equipped with an Agilent 1260 Infinity High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) system. The LC/MS system complimented an outdated 22-year-old gas chromatography/mass spectrometry system, which had limited capabilities to support a diverse range of research projects in chemistry and biology. The LC/MS instrument greatly enhanced the capabilities at Ripon College with regard to performing state-of-the-art research in biochemistry, biology, and organic synthesis. This research enabled faculty at Ripon College to train undergraduate students in a many modern techniques, such as lipid profiling, protein-ligand interactions, and preparation of pharmaceutical building blocks. The state-of-the-art accurate mass capabilities on the instrument allowed Ripon College researchers to measure mass data necessary for publication in peer-reviewed journals.

Several noteworthy outcomes emerged from using the LC/MS in these collaborative undergraduate research settings. Specifically, PI Patrick Willoughby worked with students to discovered a new approach to preparing N,O-acetals, a useful building block in the synthesis of pharmaceutical agents. The LC/MS enabled Willoughby and students to determine the identity all new compounds and examine details of the reaction mechanism. After purchasing an additional component, the LC/MS further aided studies into the development of a stereoselective approach for the synthesis of N,O-acetals, which included preparation of novel, carbon-based catalysts. These results have led to new avenues of study for Willoughby and his students, and would not be possible without the data acquired on the new LC/MS technology.

Co-PI Robert Wallace worked with students on three projects. These were as follows. This research (1) established protocols to determine the lipid (fatty acid profiles) of well fed Brachionus plicatilis (Rotifera; Gnesiotrocha; Monogononta), (2) monitored and identified the lipids in B. plicatilis over a starvation period of 72 hours, and (3) identified the lipid profiles of zooplankton (mostly rotifers) colonizing an outdoor, commercial, algal culture ponds with different diets. The established protocols allowed the researchers to monitor >35 different fatty acids in the target organisms. 

Co-PI Colleen Byron worked with students to deduce the locations of amino acid modifications by a peroxylipid byproduct, 4-hydroxy-nonenal, known to be generated in mitochondria by oxidative stress.  Here the mitochondrial protein of interest was electron transfer flavoprotein (ETF), an enzyme that accepts electrons from the oxidation of fats and other biomolecules and shuttles them into membrane bound components of the electron transport chain.  Students first explored how to use the LC/MS to probe adduction of 4-hydroxy-nonenal to small peptides to become familiar with the technology.  Following this, students began working through data generated by the larger ETF protein using a combination of LC/MS data and online protein mass databases.  High resolution mass data are critical to attribution of adducts to specific locations on the protein.

The instrument was made available to neighboring institutions free of charge, and varying degrees of instrument training were provided to a number of members within the Ripon community. In addition to the enabling the purchase of new instrument, the project resulted in publication of a peer-reviewed article and an issued patent, as well as numerous undergraduate theses and conference presentations.
